title: Pat Abbott
text:
Buell Patrick Abbott (January 18, 1912 – 1984) was an American professional <a href="golf">golf</a>er. 
Abbott was born in <a href="Pasadena%2C%20California">Pasadena, California</a>. In 1936, he won the <a href="U.S.%20Amateur%20Public%20Links">U.S. Amateur Public Links</a>, beating Claude Rippy 4 & 3. In 1938, he lost the <a href="U.S.%20Amateur">U.S. Amateur</a> to <a href="Willie%20Turnesa">Willie Turnesa</a> 8 & 7. He would lose the U.S. Amateur again in 1941 to <a href="Bud%20Ward">Bud Ward</a> 4 & 3. He won the 1942 <a href="Western%20Amateur">Western Amateur</a> as well as the Southern California Amateur, twice, and the Southern California Open in 1935.
Abbott turned professional after <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> and served as a club pro at Memphis Country Club in <a href="Memphis%2C%20Tennessee">Memphis, Tennessee</a> for 34 years. He won the <a href="Tennessee%20Open">Tennessee Open</a> four times and the Tennessee PGA Senior Championship three times. 
Abbott was inducted into the Tennessee Golf Hall of Fame in 2002.
